contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to bring Ezekiel's attention to what the people were doing. Alternate translation: "I want you to understand why I hate what the people here are doing." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: do you see what they are doing?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is commanding Ezekiel to look at what the elders are doing. Alternate translation: "look at what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: do you see what the elders of the house of Israel are doing in the dark?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. Alternate translation: "Think about this ... man." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you see this ... man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. Alternate translation: "Think about this ... man." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you see this ... man?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses this question to show that he is right to be angry at the people of Judah. Alternate translation: "I am right to be angry at the house of Judah because of these abominations that they are doing here." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it a little thing for the house of Judah to do these abominations that they are doing here?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knewâ€”that the people had asked him this question. Alternate translation: "Son of man, the house of Israel, that rebellious house, is asking, 'What are you doing?'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Son of man, is the house of Israel, that rebellious house, not asking, 'What are you doing?'

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a mild rebuke for the people who use the proverb. Alternate translation: "the people in the land of Israel have this proverb that says, 'The days are prolonged, and every vision fails.' (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: what is this proverb that you have in the land of Israel that says, 'The days are prolonged, and every vision fails'?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses a question to rebuke the false prophets. Alternate translation: "You have had false visions ... because I myself have not spoken." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you not had false visions ... when I myself have not spoken?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that others will ask the prophets what happened to their whitewash. Alternate translation: "Others will certainly say to you, 'Where is the whitewash that you put on it?'" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have others not said to you, "Where is the whitewash that you put on it?"

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) that this is an honest question for which the people expect and answer or 2) this is a rhetorical question that the people ask out of sarcasm. Alternate translation: "The whitewash that you put on it did no good." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Where is the whitewash that you put on it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to rebuke the women who do these things. The implicit answer is, "no." Alternate translation: "Do not think that you will be able to save your own lives after you have hunted down my people!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you hunt down my people but save your own lives?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the elders should not be inquiring of him. This question can be translated as a statement. It can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Should I permit them to inquire of me at all?" or "They should not be inquiring of me at all." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Should I be inquired of at all by them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "a vine is not better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: how is a vine better than any tree with branches that is among the trees in a forest?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "People do not take wood from a vine to make anything." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do people take wood from a vine to make anything?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "they do not make a peg from it to hang things on it." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: do they make a peg from it to hang anything on it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel of something he already knows. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "If it is thrown into a fire as fuel ... it is not good for anything." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: If it is thrown into a fire as fuel ... is it good for anything?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the woman is acting as if her prostitution was not bad enough and so she decided to sacrifice her children as well. This can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You must think that your acts of prostitution are a small matter." or "I do not think your acts of prostitution are a small matter." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are your acts of prostitution a small matter?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks the rhetorical question in order to rebuke Jerusalem. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "Your heart must be very sick ... that you would do all these things, deeds of a shameless prostitute!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How sick is your heart ... that you would do all these things, deeds of a shameless prostitute?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. This can be translated as as statement. Alternate translation: "It will not prosper." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will it prosper?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the vine will certainly be judged. The question can be translated as a statement. It can also be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "Someone will pull up its roots and pluck out its fruit so all of its growth of leaves will wither away." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: Will it not be uprooted and stripped of its fruit so that it withers, and all its fresh growth will wither?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question to emphasize the negative answer. The question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "It will not grow." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: will it grow?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that this will certainly happen. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "It will wither when the eastern wind touches it." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will it not wither when the eastern wind touches it?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to provide the answer. The question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "This is what these things mean." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do you not know what these things mean?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "He will certainly not succeed." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will he succeed?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. This may be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "The one doing these things will not escape." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will the one doing these things escape?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the negative answer. This question can be translated as as statement. Alternate translation: "If he breaks the covenant, he will certainly not escape." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: If he breaks the covenant, will he escape?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this leading question to emphasize the affirmative answer. This question can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "it was my oath that the king of Jerusalem despised and my covenant that he broke." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: was it not my oath that he despised and my covenant that he broke?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to remind Ezekiel something he already knows. The question is a rebuke for the people who use the proverb. Alternate translation: "The people in the land of Israel have this proverb ... 'Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt'." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What do you mean, you who use this proverb ... 'Fathers eat sour grapes, and the children's teeth are made blunt'?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this as a leading question in order to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: "he will certainly not live!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: should that man live? Surely he will not!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question in order to emphasize the opposite. Alternate translation: "I do not greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked ... but I do greatly rejoice if he turns away from his way so that he may live." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Do I greatly rejoice over the death of the wicked ... and not in his turning away from his way so that he may live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: "then he will surely not live." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: then will he live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the negative answer. Alternate translation: "My ways are not unfair." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are my ways unfair?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize the positive answer. Alternate translation: "It is your ways that are unfair." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it not your ways that are unfair?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to comfort the people of Israel. Alternate translation: "There is no reason for you to die, house of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why should you die, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this ask a leading question in order to introduce the answer. Alternate translation: "This is who your mother is." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who was your mother?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this rhetorical question to emphasize that the elders should not be inquiring of him. Alternate translation: "You should not come to inquire of me." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you come to inquire of me?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question in order to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: "This is not a high place where you are to bring offerings!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: What is this high place where you bring offerings there?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: "You should not make yourselves unclean by doing the things that your fathers did." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Why do you make yourselves unclean with the ways of your fathers?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: "You should not act like prostitutes, searching for disgusting things." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: So why do you act like prostitutes, searching for disgusting things?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh asks this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: "I will not let you come close to me, house of Israel." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: So why should I let you seek me, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use this question to insult Ezekiel and dismiss what he is telling them. Alternate translation: "He is merely telling parables" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Is he not a mere teller of parables?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question emphasizes that the people of Israel will not celebrate their king's power, because it cannot resist the "sword." Alternate translation: "The people of Judah will not celebrate about their king's scepter." or "we should not celebrate the power of our king's scepter." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should we rejoice in my son's scepter?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This rhetorical question functions as a command. AT. "Son of man, go and judge. Go and judge the city of blood." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Now you, son of man, will you judge? Will you judge the city of blood?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question to emphasize how hurt they will be when he punishes them. This question may be written as a statement. Alternate translation: "Your heart will not stand and your hands will not be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will your heart stand, will your hands be strong on the days when I myself will deal with you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this rhetorical question as a command for Ezekiel. This question can be written as a statement. The cities of Jerusalem and Samaria are represented by Oholah and Oholibah. Alternate translation: "Son of man, you will judge Oholah and Oholibah!" or "Son of man, judge the people of those two cities represented by Oholah and Oholibah." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Son of man, will you judge Oholah and Oholibah?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a positive answer and emphasizes the results of Tyre's destruction. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "The islands will quake ... in your midst." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Will not the islands quake ... in your midst?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a negative answer and emphasizes Tyre being different from all other cities. It can be expressed as a statement. Alternate translation: "No other city is like Tyre, who has now been brought to silence in the middle of the sea." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Who is like Tyre, who has now been brought to silence in the middle of the sea?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question expects a negative answer to emphasize the irony when one who claims to be a god is destroyed by men. It can be translated as a statement. Alternate translation: "You will not say 'I am a god' to the face of one who kills you!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-irony]])
contextId.glQuote: Will you truly say, "I am a god" to the face of one who kills you?

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Who is as great as you are?" Yahweh uses this question to introduce a new topic. Pharaoh thought that his nation was the greatest, but God is about to talk about another great nation. Alternate translation: "You think that there is no country whose power is as great as the power of your country." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: In your greatness, who are you like?

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Which of these trees in Eden had as much glory as you and was as great as you?" God asks Pharaoh this question to show him that the parable applies to him and his country. It can start with "So Pharaoh" or "So Egypt." Alternate translation: "None of the trees in Eden was your equal in glory and greatness!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Which of the trees in Eden was your equal in glory and greatness?

contextId.occurrenceNote: This question really makes a statement. Alternate translation: "You are not more beautiful than anyone else." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are you really more beautiful than anyone else?

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people ask this question to emphasize that they have no hope of living. Alternate translation: "We have no hope of living." or "We will certainly die." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: How can we live?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he does not want the people of Israel to die. Alternate translation: "Do not choose to die, house of Israel!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: For why should you die, house of Israel?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh used this question to rebuke the people. Alternate translation: "You should not possess this land!" or "You do not deserve this land!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should you really possess the land?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to scold the leaders for not taking care of the people. Alternate translation: "Shepherds should feed the flock and take care of it." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Should not shepherds guard the flock?

contextId.occurrenceNote: God uses these questions to scold Israel's leaders, who are spoken of as if they were the stronger animals in the flock that were unkind to the weaker ones. You can translate this as a statement as in the UST. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Is it not enough ... feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people use a question to express their surprise at what they saw. Alternate translation: "I cannot believe these are really the people of Yahweh!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are these really the people of Yahweh?

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two questions are used to accuse Gog of attacking Israel without cause. These can be translated as statements. Alternate translation: "It is not right for you to assemble your army to plunder, to carry off silver and gold, to take their livestock and property, and to haul away much plunder!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Have you come to plunder? Have you assembled your armies ... to haul away much plunder?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that Gog will indeed hear about the people living in Israel. Alternate translation: "On that day, when my people Israel are living securely, you will hear about them." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: On that day ... learn about them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh uses this question to emphasize that he was the one who brought Gog to the land of Israel. Alternate translation: "You are the one ... bring you against them." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: Are you not the one ... bring you against them?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is commanding Ezekiel to think about what he has just seen. See how you translated this in [Ezekiel 8:15](../08/15.md). Alternate translation: "think about this." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-rquestion]])
contextId.glQuote: do you see this?
